Quickstart#

Installation#

  1. Clone the package

    git clone "https://github.com/FrancisH-C/TSload"

  2. Run the installation from the package root folder

    python -m pip install -e .

Basics#

Dataset#

The collection of all the data stored in a single path is called the dataset.

The data#

The datatype refers type of the data which informs about the structure of the data. A given datatype as the exact same features. Datatype is a collection of multiple categories of input from different ID. The datatype can be stored in a sequence of split.

The Metadata#

Every dataset has metadata that gives information about every datatype. Here is a simple example metadata information.

datatype = "Stocks"
split = ["date1", "date2"]
ID = ["ABC", "XYZ"]
features = ["side", "quantity", "price"]

Note that the data is separated on two files using the split.

Usage#

Use exactly one loader per datatype.

Initialization#

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from TSload import TSloader, DataFormat

path = "data/example_simple"
datatype = "simulated"
loader = TSloader(path, datatype)

Write data#

  1. Add datatype

    Create a DataFrame

    d = {"ID": np.hstack((["name1" for _ in range(5)], ["name2" for _ in range(5)])),
    "timestamp": list(map(str, range(0,10))),
     "feature0": list(range(10)), "feature1": list(range(10,20))}
df = pd.DataFrame(data=d)

    loader.initialize_datatype(df=df)
loader.df

  2. Add ID

    Create a DataFrame

    ID = "added_ID"
d_ID = {"timestamp": list(map(str, range(0,5))), "feature0": list(range(5)) ,"feature1": list(range(10,15))}
df = pd.DataFrame(data=d_ID)

    loader.add_ID(df, ID=ID, collision="overwrite")
print(loader.metadata) # in memory
print(loader.df) # in memory

  3. Add feature

    It is definitely easier to add the datatype correctly in the first place than to use add_feature. Here, we add feature for name1.

    Create a DataFrame

    ID = "added_ID"
feature = "added_feature"
d = {"timestamp": list(map(str, range(4))), feature: list(range(10, 14))}
df = pd.DataFrame(data=d)

    loader.add_feature(df, ID=ID, feature=feature)
print(loader.df)
    RESULTS

  4. Write data on disk

    Don’t forget to write the changes on disk.

    loader.write()

Load data#

read_loader = TSloader(path, datatype, permission="read")

  1. Data

    print(read_loader.df)

  2. Metadata

    An important note about metadata, is that it is unordered. Thus, the order can change without notice.

    print(read_loader.metadata)
